clinical_study.brief_title: Fertility Preservation in Female Cancer Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Vitrification of Oocytes From Female Cancer Patients to Preserve Their Fertility Potential

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to preserve the fertility potential in females diagnosed with cancer by vitrifying (rapidly freezing) their oocytes (eggs) before undergoing treatment for their cancer.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Study technique has been declared part of standard care

primary_outcome.time_frame: nine months after transfer of embryo(s)
primary_outcome.description: the primary objective of this study is the establishment of a successful pregnancy, following a disease-free interval after treatment for her cancer; this interval will be patient-dependent and will undoubtedly vary between participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: impact of stimulation on cancer recurrence
secondary_outcome.description: patients will be followed for five years following cancer treatment to assess the risks associated with ovarian stimulation and the recurrence of cancer.

arm_group.description: female patients diagnosed with cancer who wish to preserve their fertility by vitrifying their oocytes

intervention.description: freezing of the patient's retrieved oocytes via vitrification (rapid freezing)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients must be 14-42 year old females with a cancer diagnosis.
- Clearance letter from treating oncologist.
- Approval by program oncologist or her designee.
- Informed consent has to be signed after consultation with the program physician. Minors require consent of a parent or a legal guardian and assent from the participant.
- Life expectancy (predicted by their malignancy) of 5 or more years.
- Cancer diagnosis should have an expected cure rate of 50% or more, based upon clinico-pathologic features.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients whose oncologist and the program oncologist concur that immediate oncologic care should be rendered, not allowing sufficient time for a course of gonadotropin therapy and egg retrieval.
- FSH level >20 MIU/ml, indicating abnormal ovarian function.
- Patients with stage IV cancers (*age appropriate women with stage IV advanced Hodgkin's Lymphoma will be considered, as there is a significant long term survival rate with this advanced disease).
- Patients with incurable cancer diagnoses.
- Patients who are unable or unwilling to sign the informed consent.
- Women cannot have an embryo transfer beyond age 50.
